instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message: It's not too often I see a device where all of the USB-C ports pull basically zero current (Starts at 0.01A and drops to 0.0A) with no looping or other activity, but that's the case on this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05. No liquid damage or issues spotted with a visual inspection, pretty through check for shorts didn't turn up anything, customer reports sudden death. Anything in particular that's common on this model that I should check for before spending an hour going through every power rail in the <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> startup sequence? The best reference I've found so far is [URL]https://logi.wiki/index.php/CD3217_and_T2_Power_on_Sequenc[/URL], but that's a heck of a lot of rails to test and not specific to this board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
First step for T2 machine, check if is recognized in DFU.
If not, then need to get into hardware.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message: Actually <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0.099V diode drop to ground, which is surprising given it didn't beep during an initial quick check. Every CPU related coil measures approx 0.1V drop to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, what all do I need to check before safely injecting power?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 85276, member: 682"]
First step for T2 machine, check if is recognized in DFU.
If not, then need to get into hardware.
[/QUOTE]
I don't have a working USB-C machine on hand to test with at the moment, but given the above update, I believe that indicates a certain hardware issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message: Okay, did a lot of measurements and determined the CPU fets should be good, so I injected 13.1V into <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, consumed about 250mA and <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> got warm, found <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> to have low resistance (About 6 Ohms, but randomly drops to nearly 0 on occasion), so I injected 2.5V into that rail which consumed 250mA, but on occasion randomly jumps to 4Amps for a few seconds (I've observed this repeatedly, I'm not accidently shorting anything). <CHIP>U9400</CHIP> gets warm with 3 distinct hot spots that melt first when using freeze spray. Is this adequate to conclude that this NAND chip has died? What do I need to do to replace this NAND chip? Can I just swap this one and dfu restore afterwards or is it a more complex process?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
Pufff, injecting 13V directly; too risky, don't do this again.

Did you check diode mode to ground at L9580 first?
What if there was 0.099 (meaning L9580 shorted to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>)?

We have few threads about changing NAND chips, but nobody left a feedback about did it and succeed.
Of course, DFU is needed in such case.
Some people claim on Internet they got it swapping with NAND from the same position on the donor board.

BTW, do not write the end "V" after diode mode reading; avoid voltage confusion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
In the future, how would you recommend finding a partial secondary short with low power consumption if not by injecting on the main rail? I started at 1V and worked up very gradually while monitoring the outputs of every independent fet I could find to determine that there wasn't a significant risk before cranking up the power.

I didn't check at L9580 first, and certainly see your point, but also from experience I believe it's a lot less common for an integrated buck IC like this to short the input rail to the output than with independent fets. What do you suggest instead when most everything on the board shows a low diode drop?

I'm willing to go through with changing all the NAND chips + controller + rom if need be as this is a pretty expensive device, but I'm struggling to come up with any definitive answers on this. I suppose I'll just have to get a donor and start with one, and swap the rest if it doesn't work. I don't suppose it would be possible to use an iPhone NAND programmer to clone the low level data to another NAND chip I already have laying around, would it?

Will do, thanks for your help!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
If a NAND chips is bad and need to be replaced, I bet you cannot even read it, no?

We talked a lot about how and NOT to inject voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> power rail on the forum.
ALWAYS check first for shorted high-side MOSFETs; including the ones integrated on the power chips.
If you search the forum, will find lot of threads with shorted <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>/580!

BTW, you've didn't mention to started voltage injection with 1V; just said injected 13V...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
There's been some recent developments with reading sysconfig data from dead iPhone NANDs, generally it's more focused on when the damage prevents access to the main partitions but still allows the sysconfig regions to be read with some software tricks, but I've also had success with using this on partially shorted NANDs while injecting external power. Maybe I'll give it a go, probably can't hurt.

Interesting, I'm surprised the integrated fets short that often, I will check that in the future! Fair point, I was trying to summarize a lot of testing that I did.

Assuming the customer approves the quote, I'll let you know what I find wrt NAND swapability.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
Finding donor NAND's for this board has been quite the saga, but now I'm afraid it might have been in vain.

I removed <CHIP>U9400</CHIP>, the NAND that was getting warm, after which <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> still has a diode reading of 0.018, which seems low to me. This is the exact same value as it had before, expect previously when I injected 1V into <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL>, the board consumed 5A, now it only consumes 80mA.

Upon powering the board, <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> alternates between 1.5V and 3V in 3-5 second intervals. Previously it was partially shorted and nearly 0V. This is not what I expected to find, and I'm pretty confused as to how I'm getting 3V on a 2.5V line that's switched off of a subsidiary of PPBUS. Does this point to swapping 6x NANDs being a waste of time? Or what could possibly be going on here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message: Additional note: Before removing <CHIP>U9400</CHIP>, the board consumed 0.01A at 5V when powered, now it consumes 0.110A at 20V, so I feel confident the NAND was the issue, but I don't understand the present situation.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
[QUOTE="Alex Thayer, post: 86340, member: 34273"]
Finding donor NAND's for this board has been quite the saga, but now I'm afraid it might have been in vain.

I removed <CHIP>U9400</CHIP>, the NAND that was getting warm, after which <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> still has a diode reading of 0.018, which seems low to me. This is the exact same value as it had before, expect previously when I injected 1V into <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL>, the board consumed 5A, now it only consumes 80mA.

Upon powering the board, <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> alternates between 1.5V and 3V in 3-5 second intervals. Previously it was partially shorted and nearly 0V. This is not what I expected to find, and I'm pretty confused as to how I'm getting 3V on a 2.5V line that's switched off of a subsidiary of PPBUS. Does this point to swapping 6x NANDs being a waste of time? Or what could possibly be going on here?
[/QUOTE]

Where did you take the donors from? Exact same board or maybe iphone?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
[QUOTE="Maltinho, post: 86345, member: 34883"]
Where did you take the donors from? Exact same board or maybe iphone?
[/QUOTE]
I have not installed any donor NANDs yet. Just removed the shorted NAND and observed that somehow I'm getting 1.5 to 3v on a 2.5v line. I'm familiar with the need to transfer a complete set of NANDs from a select list of compatible boards and match up the clock request line IDs and not doing anything silly. I have an exact match donor board in this case.

If you're asking for yourself, unless you've developed a new programmer tool, you can't use an iPhone NAND, there's system configuration data on each NAND that's used to configure the raid array under the hood. There's not a programmer available for transferring or generating this, so you must swap a complete set of NANDs from another board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
"I'm pretty confused as to how I'm getting 3V on a 2.5V line"
Did you check the voltage at correct output pin of the coils?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message: Yes, both sides of L9581, and every other spot I've probed <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> show the exact same behavior. To get more specific on the timing, <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> is 3.07V for about 15 seconds, then drops to 1.51V for about 2 seconds, and then repeats in a loop. This isn't the output of the buck collapsing and residual voltage on the line leaking slowly. The transitions between 3V and 1.5V are sharp, and those levels are stable for their respective periods.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message: You may have problem with <RESISTOR>R9580</RESISTOR>/81/83 voltage divider, or <CAPACITOR>C9582</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C9582</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C9585</CAPACITOR> are not shorted, capacity test in circuit didn't work but I can pull either if that's helpful.
<RESISTOR>R9583</RESISTOR> is 10 ohms as expected.
<RESISTOR>R9580</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R9581</RESISTOR> both measure 150K but show as 475K and 221K on my <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A schematic.

Could this be due to differences between the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 board designs? Looking at the circuit topography makes me feel like this isn't the result of them just being in circuit, as they have almost the exact same value. I can pull them and measure if pertinent.

Should I take voltage measurements throughout the buck circuit?

Just to be extra clear, I have a NAND removed, this isn't the cause of the elevated voltage, right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
The removed NAND cannot change the voltage.

Change <CAPACITOR>C9582</CAPACITOR>, just in case.
Is not about short there; its capacity sets the soft start time.

<RESISTOR>R9580</RESISTOR>/81 value must be checked out of board.
You can play with the mentioned resistors to adjust output voltage.
Increasing <RESISTOR>R9581</RESISTOR> will decrease the output voltage.
Get the same result decreasing <RESISTOR>R9580</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
No change with <CAPACITOR>C9582</CAPACITOR>, after removing the original I verified the correct capacitance of 2.2nF

<RESISTOR>R9580</RESISTOR> and 81 have the correct values when removed from the board and tested externally

Is there any way that tinkering with the feedback voltage divider could solve my cycling problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
Well, I think I figured it out... This board is a trip.

Board was sitting across the room with USB-C power connected with the same behavior as before I removed and replaced the passives, when <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> suddenly exploded, and the right 12 pads were completely vaporized. After removing the remains of <CHIP>U9580</CHIP>, I found <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> to be completely shorted and PPBUS to be unaffected. The short is now in NAND chip <CHIP>U9100</CHIP>.

My analysis is that <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> was intermittently failing and originally killed <CHIP>U9400</CHIP>, causing the system to cut power. After I removed the short, the elevated voltage on <CHIP>U9580</CHIP>'s output was a result of it being on it's last legs, and when I saw it explode PPBUS was connected to <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL>, killing a second NAND chip and causing the short to return. Sound right to you?

So, from here... I was planning to replace all the NANDs anyway, is that still realistic in addition to <CHIP>U9580</CHIP>? Or now that we know that <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> probably got hit by PPBUS, is there a high likelihood of severe damage to other circuits such that I should call it quits? Looking at the schematic, <CHIP>U9500</CHIP> is the only other IC that strikes me as likely to have been impacted.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
If you are not afraid to change the NANDs chip, do it.
You can't lose more than time now.

I recommend to change <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> and check its output before placing the new NANDs.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
While I'm comfortable flipping NANDs, donor boards with 6x NANDs in a high capacity SSD configuration are extremely expensive, so I'm very hesitant to take the NANDs off my $275 donor board unless I'm confident this is going to work.

I've now removed all six NANDs, and replaced <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> with <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> for testing. Now I have 2.5V on <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL>, but every 15 seconds or so the output collapses to nearly 0V for about a second. I noticed that PPBUS is going from 12.6V to 12.3V on the same schedule, is this normal for a board with no NANDs? The power consumption on my ammeter is steady at 0.05A 20V. After digging out the burned fiberglass, there was a huge hole in the board and I had to replace pretty much every pad that was not ground with a jumper, so it's possible there's a bad connection to <CHIP>U9580</CHIP>, but I don't see how this would cause PPBUS to fluctuate and I'm pretty confident in my soldering.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
T2 has its firmware partition on SSD.
Bad SSD will also cause T2 problems.

I recommend to keep the NANDs for other board repair.
This one may be unrepairable...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
Thank you for your insights and advice on this project!

My hope is that because the T2 can’t find its firmware, the system automatically resets after 15 seconds and that’s why I see fluctuations in PPBUS and other rails.

So last question - Any idea if it’s normal to see some sort of an automatic reset loop when the SSD isn’t functioning, isn’t powered, or has been removed?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message: Update: I verified with a working board, removing  <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> caused the behavior described above. I will be proceeding with the SSD transplant.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
Unfortunately I'm stuck in DFU after the NAND transplant, here's what I did:

-Verified that no NAND power rails were shorted on the donor board
-Replaced <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> on the customer board, verified that all NAND voltages were now stable
-Moved 6x NANDs from an identical donor board with the same size SSD (1TB)
-Placed all NANDs in the exact same location as on the donor
-Replaced any small components that were knocked off, verified everything missing nearby was no stuff on the donor
-Checked for shorts on major NAND power rails, then powered up in DFU
-Verified that all NAND voltages were as expected

DFU restore gave error 4042 on the first attempt and 16383 on the second attempt. The progress bar quickly approaches the end of step 4 of 4, but then hangs for several minutes before producing an error. There's not much info online about these errors, I'm feeling totally stuck. I'm very confident in my soldering and pretty surprised this didn't work out, any suggestions?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
NAND chips are directly connected with T2.
The overvoltage could affected it too...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message: Any way to diagnose this or make sense of those error codes? Can I replace T2?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
As already said, nobody left positive feedback on the forum about NAND swap.
Same apply for T2 replace.
I appreciate the feedback from your experiment, but maybe didn't choose the best machine to do this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
I hear you... If I transplant the T2 from the donor board, could that theoretically work?

I see so many of these newer boards dead in the water and would like to raise the repair rate even if it takes throwing in some time and practice at NAND and T2 swaps, in particular this board is work about $1k when working.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 5V 0.00-0.01A on all USB-C Ports
threads.message:
I said, no positive feedback left on the forum.
People claimed to done it on Internet.

There is some information can't be copied; ID code is baked into T2.
